name: Spell Immune (or Nearly Spell Immune) Divine Zen Arbalest Concept
author: Orion

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Tried to reverse engineer @Ten Pura 's Spell Immune Divine Zen Arbalest Concept.

I believed that would be a Monk 39 / Cleric 1 build with Improved Spell Resistance IX and Epic Weapon Focus: Heavy Crossbow.

Divine Might taken pre-epic, other feats include Blind Fight, Called Shot, Rapid Reload, weapon focus and improved critical.

For my own version designed for PvM I thought adding an Rogue level for UMD and traps of his own would be useful. 

Making the build 'nearly spell immune' with intrinsic SR 66. Spell Immunity is obtained at 67, to make a level 40 caster with epic spell penetration unable to pass a SR check. 66 means a 5% chance of such a caster succeeding, and no other lvl 40 casters being able to succeed.

Other alternatives included a paladin level for divine grace, but the charisma was not especially high, or Fighter/Ranger for a feat. Overall I felt rogue added more, including skill dumps for search (for traps)

Discipline is in here to prevent called shots (arm or leg) and disarms. Knockdown's I can see as a potential way of dying but it isn't high enough to prevent a serious improved knockdown attempt from a fighter so knockdown immunity items would be very useful.

In terms of Domains, Animal would be the most useful for empowered summons from scrolls or wands given you are a ranged character. The other Domain is up for debate, good ones include Trickery, Healing or War. If one wishes to take this one on WoG one should probably choose Plant. 

Dealing with the AB issue with either build is of interest to me. Using equipment or UMD spells would be the approach I would be looking at

I suspect that the high spell resistance aspect of both builds means that scrolls of divine power that are used in combat will not be dispelled? Likewise scrolls of PnP Tensors as well.

If sequencers are available such scrolls can be put into them. 

I think WebShaman or Ten Pura might have some answers for that given their experience with high ISR builds.

Overall I thought the halfling one looked the best out of the two.

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
First of all, with an SR of 67, the build is pretty much immune to spells (39+10, 9x2=18, so 49+18=67) as this is higher than anything can get with ESP and 40 levels of Spellcaster (40+20 on a 1d20+6=66).

So it might be worth looking into a 3rd class for that yummy UMD.

I am not sure how dispel works against SR, but theoretically, DP and PnP TT could be Breached off, I suppose.  I don't think that SR "protects" spells from being dispelled, but I could be wrong.  In any event, if one has UMD, one can cast scrolls of Spell Mantle, which should absorb Dispel, I believe.
A spell resistance check actually involves three defenses. The defenses in the order they are checked are spell level absorption (mantles), spell immunity, then spell resistance. That is, a spell that does not check spell resistance is not affected by any of these defenses.
Though it says under Dispel Magic
dispel magic does not check spell resistance.
So go figure.

The great thing is the build can go Fists whenever it needs to.  It might even be a better Fister (hehe...) than Xbow user!

This may well be me being over-simplistic (in which case I'm sure you eager-beavers will correct me), but in the case above surely one tactic is not to have any buffing or other spells up - so they can't be dispelled?

If dispel magic doesn't check spell resistance, then it follows from Web's snippets that absorption and immunity don't apply, and can therefore be dispelled. However, Monk SR is not a spell, so cannot be dispelled. So just build a good grunt!

Happy to be gainsaid here. But still feel obliged to say: "bloody casters, complicating everything..."

One strategy against AI at least is to bait out all the dispels with a few lightly buffed low level summon creatures, or light buffs of your own from potions of barkskin or ironguts etc whatever you can get, build up enough cheap stuff the AI hates it and will try to get rid of it.

Thanks for pointing out I could swap EWF for ISR for a further +2 SR creating room for an additional rogue level plus retaining spell immunity. The current drafts finish on 66. One could take fighter 2 for free EWF and EP for +3 AB and retain SR 67.

I guess to answer your question Stag - the AB is terrible on these builds. Sadly one of the trade offs of spell immunity (Or near immunity). Getting AB boosts from cleric DP scrolls or UMD is attractive to pump it up to hit more however the down side is dispellability which may or may not be a problem depending on the environment

posts.author: Ten Pura
posts.content:
Orion,
I was thinking of something like this:
Spoiler
The 35 unbuffed AB (37 with Sling) and 37 unbuffed AC will struggle against tough fighter/archer types, but this build is made to do one thing: kill traditional casters. With 67 SR, it is immune to most offensive spells. The general strategy for this build is to fire sling bullets and run around. If you can get your hands on breach scrolls or a wand of Lesser Spell Breach, that's even better.

Also, it has HiPS.

This is the build that I don't want to face as a caster.  My general strategy for countering this as a caster is Wand of Expeditious Retreat -> Wand of Improved Invisibility -> Run away!

Additional notes: when playing a caster, I usually don't build to overcome SR 36+. If I will hit SR 35 100%, I'm very comfortable stopping there and seeking to mitigate other weaknesses in the build (like discipline, AC, HP, et al). This means that the above build is overkill for most casters and leaves a fair amount on the table for swapping out Improved Spell Resistance feats with something more offensive in epic levels. I'm putting together a one-room module to test spell effectiveness against a SR 70 Monk, just to see what works.

My general strategy for countering this as a caster is Wand of Expeditious Retreat -> Wand of Improved Invisibility -> Run away!
I think you got that backwards, and a little bit wrong Haste, Greater Sanctuary, RUN!!!!

Because said Monk above will easily catch you if it can see you - and Improved Invis is penetrable. 

But in the event that you really use wands like that - it should be the other way around as ER doesn't last all that long, and you want to go Invis ASAP!

Be sure - be safe!

"Oh brave Sir Mage, Sir Mage ran away!"

For Dispellers (or AI that spams Dispel), I use a Wand of Mage Armor.  PfE also works fine.

Hehe.

I cast Mage Armor on myself, the AI Dispels.  Rinse, repeat until said Dispels are gone.

Now one can start popping DP and TT!

My now preferred build (Nightshade) is Elf Dex Fister Circle Kick Monk 34/Shadowdancer 5/Ass 1 (not Rogue to avoid XP penalty).  It has high SR, HiPS, ED, UMD, very high AC and good AB.  Carries a Wand of Lesser Breach for blowing off damage shields. One can also Trap, if one wants to.

Now that Circle Kick has been fixed, the extra Attack at highest BaB is very welcome, and being able to spam IKD twice a round can really come in handy (and Stunning Fist, btw).  Note that Circle Kick can frustrate a bit if one is in a great M0b and one is trying to KO the only spellcaster, but thems the breaks (with that SR, it is not likely that the spells will get you, anyway).

HiPSing while Hasted is awesome with that movement!  Even if something notices me, I am usually gone before it can react!

I love this build so much, it is hard for me to now play anything else!

posts.author: Ten Pura
posts.content:
After some testing, the knockdown effect of grease is effective against an SR 67 Monk (just to make sure, I made it a SR 70 Monk). That said, it's only a DC 25 with 38 Int and no SF: Conj feats, which means the Monk in question must roll a 1 on the Reflex save. Grease is only effective if stacked, then the Monk must save vs. each spell per round.

Great Thunderclap is much more effective, because it forces 3 saves as a level 7 spell, but it's only instant, and the negative effects (except deafened, which doesn't do much except to sorcerers/wizards) only last 1 round. On my test Wizard with 38 Int and GSF: Evocation, Great Thunderclap hit for DC 35, which on most of these builds gives me around a 50% chance for one of 1 round stun (will) or a knockdown (reflex) and a 5% (roll 1 on the save) chance on the other depending on whether the build improved Wisdom or Dexterity.

Oh, and I use Expeditious Retreat because in the environment I play, caster levels are correctly counted when crafting wands, so my Expeditious Retreat lasts over 20 rounds.

posts.author: Ten Pura
posts.content:
More testing:
Monk DR nerfs Empowered Evard's completely. Not a single point of damage inflicted on 7 or 8 stacked Empowered Evard's over the whole duration.

It seemed that Darkness worked to conceal me, and it doesn't seem to check for SR (maybe because I'm not casting it on the Monk?). Ultravision allowed me to continue to operate. The concealment/DR combo from Improved Invisibility/Greater Stoneskin/Shadow Shield worked great, but not flawlessly.

Summons and BBoD were effective. Time Stop made the most effective escape mechanism, and it let me layer on Grease spells to allow summons and BBoD more time to work. Great Thunderclap was also effective in getting time for summons to work.

Lesson learned: as a ranged mage killer, make sure to have some way to pierce magical darkness (Potion of Ultravision) and don't stand in the grease.

Darkness works as long as it is not cast on the Monk - anything that is "physical" (like Grease) that is not cast directly on the Monk itself will affect it.

Too easily defeated IMO. 

This is why GT works - it brings into existence an actual "thing" - the Thunderclap (thus the no SR thing).

Does the ol' cast a shadow magic spell and then Grease, etc still pump the DC sky high?

If so, that would really get your spell DCs up there, that should be pretty good!

Evard's is bugged. Are you using a fixed version?  And did you try Empowered?

Although being a Halfling will just take this spell right out.
  • Tiny creatures are also immune.
  • The grapple check used to determine whether or not a tentacle hits a target is as follows:
1d20 + caster level (to a maximum of 20) + 4(tentacle's strength modifier) + 4(tentacle's size modifier) versus
1d20 + base attack bonus + strength modifier + size modifier.

This makes this spell rather ineffective versus opponents with a high base attack (e.g. warriors), and stronger and larger opponents (e.g. dragons).
  • Due to a bug in the script, a medium-sized target gets a +8 bonus, as if he were of huge size.
  • The damage is intended to bypass damage reduction as a +2 weapon, but a bug in the game (not the script) prevents this.
  • Because this spell ignores spell resistance, it may prove an excellent choice for defeating magic resistant opponents.
  • Though this spell is not mind-affecting, immunity from mind-affecting effects still blocks the paralysis.
  • This spell can be devastating when used in conjunction with the empower spell feat. This is because the 50% bonus applies to both the number of tentacles from the die roll and the number of tentacles deriving from caster level, as well as applying to the damage each dealt by each tentacle.
    • If this spell is cast at maximum effectiveness (level 20 caster) at a single opponent, the total average damage is 181.5 (average of 16.5 tentacles * average of 11 damage each), assuming all tentacles hit.
    • However, the maximum damage per tentacle is only 15, allowing an effect such as ethereal visage to negate all damage from Evard's black tentacles. [

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
Unlike P&P, Monks do not become outsiders in NWN.
NWNWiki wrote:At level 20, monks receive glowing eyes. The color of the glow depends on the character's alignment: good glows blue, evil glows red, and neutral glows purple. This occurs because in pencil-and-paper, 20th-level monks become outsiders; however, in NWN, their race does not change.
Scroll down to the top of the Notes section on this page: https://nwn.fandom.com/wiki/Monk

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
Well, I am of two minds about Dex vs Wis.

As a Ranged specialist, both are pretty good - Wis has the advantage of not being "lost" if flatfooted, so it does not need any additional support to prevent AC loss. But it cannot apply to melee, unfortunately (Zen Fist ftw!!!).  Also, no Races in NWN give bonus Wis.

Dex, on the other hand, has the bonus of applying also to melee (finesse) and there are NWN Standard Races that have racial bonuses to Dex.  This gives the Dex based Ranged a higher potential AB.  But the Dex bonus to AC needs to be "fixed" with feats from other Classes.

I am leaning towards Dex, to be honest.  It appears to be a tick more flexible, with less investment necessary in outside Class dips, as the Wis based version seems to be (because the Wis based version does have a slight AB problem if it has to melee).

The Dex route also can lead to ED (Epic Dodge) - which I consider to be one of the OP Feats, alongside Dev Crit, etc.
